Measuring and monitoring soil organic matter (OM) is crucial in combating climate change. Organic matter not only improves soil health but also has several co-benefits, such as preventing soil erosion and preserving the water table. However, monitoring OM is a challenging problem due to the high cost of sampling and measuring soil attributes, which can be as expensive as $1444 on average in the US. Moreover, accurate and reliable measurement of soil properties requires sampling at intervals of every tens of meters.

To address this issue, researchers have explored using data-driven machine learning (ML) methods to infer insights about OM from other soil characteristics and remote sensing information. While sensor data provides high-fidelity insights and captures the variability in dominant soil processes, collecting data from sensors is expensive. On the other hand, remote sensing data is inexpensive and widely available for different parts of the world, particularly in low-income regions where the effects of climate change are prominent.

However, insights from remote sensing data may be biased due to noise and coarse-scale resolution. To overcome this, domain adaptation has been useful in overcoming some of the challenges due to remote sensing data and adapting models to differing land types and countries. These studies conclude that domain adaptation helps improve generalization to other domains or regions.

We propose a scalable and generalizable domain adaptation framework for mitigating bias from remote sensing data using sparse sensor data as auxiliary data. Our framework leverages the underlying causal structure in the data and preserves the relation between sensor data attributes and OM in the posterior OM distribution across different regions. We also leverage the spatial heterogeneity in the sensor attributes to improve generalization to out-of-distribution locations by influencing embeddings via contrastive learning.

Our analysis identifies key soil attributes that affect organic matter, potentially improving understanding of how to optimize soil management practices and standardize data collection approaches. We use a CNN autoencoder as the backbone model, which estimates OM from satellite imagery data. To improve the encodings learned by the autoencoder framework, we incorporate two regularization schemes: causal constraint minimization and contrastive learning.

Causal constraint minimization has been implemented to improve generalization under distributional shifts in computer vision benchmark datasets. We extend this framework to a setting with continuous attributes and a continuous response variable on a real-world dataset. We modify the framework to incorporate regularization to ensure that the relation between the sensor data attributes and OM is preserved in the posterior OM distribution across different regions.
